eLYk9hkGJN1XgNvRuZvZ6Q.text: Living a 8 minute walk from Wild Food Cafe, I eat there probably once a week. Everything on their menu is yummy - I normally get either the salad special, the raw pizza or the veggie burger with baked sweet potato fries. Their dessert specials are always hard to resist too! They are a great spot, and I am lucky to have them in this area as it makes eating vegan that much easier and more delicious! One thing of note though is that I find the space itself to be rather cramped, especially since it gets very busy during peak times and on the weekends. This, coupled with the slow service, means that I normally just call ahead and take out when I am craving something form Wild Food. However, I know they just remodeled their space, so perhaps this will aid in the facilitation of a more comfortable dining experience.

K_n3U6XSri6PEqijDZVg9g.text: Great ingredients, bland flavors. If I'm going to spend $60 on lunch for two, it shouldn't taste like something I've made with fresh produce from the farmer's market, it should taste like a world class meal.

v7gKeiz1OoyQtaYDYiKGMA.text: A bit tricky to find but that was part of the fun of this small vegetarian place with communal tables. My wife had a fabulous salad while I had the seed "burger" with coconut bacon. Very unique place with unique food.

-zFoIYwTo0Kbsa-MVWicbw.text: I would give this place just a hair above 3 stars.  There were highs and lows to my visit.  I'll start with the high points. The food is very inventive.  Everything I ate on the special meal platter was novel and intriguing.  The jamaican platter had 4 servings of different raw and vegetarian creations that were arranged artfully on the plate.  Visual appeal was definitely a strength.On the flip side, the meal took a very long time to prepare, especially considering everything was pre-made and just needed plating.  The staff used heart shaped cookie cutters to later different components of the meal in a contained heart on the plate.  I think it took about 20 minutes to produce 4 plates!Unfortunately, half of the menu was no longer available for dinner - we arrived at 7:30pm or so.  There was also quite a bit of miscommunication with and by the staff.  We ordered half orders of the daily special meal, received full orders unknowingly and were billed for the full portion.  We also had to ask several times for water, the bill, our drinks, etc.  The servers were, however, very apologetic and ended up charging us for the half portion we intended to order.  I think they have a few logistical kinks to work out, but there is a lot of potential for a great experience here.

i2b6oadm1OPIcYZIngag_g.text: I went for a take away in this cafe, got this heart beets salad and when i saw the price ( expensive one )i thought: mmmh i m gonna try it coz the ingredients seemed amazingly delish! Well when i got out the cafe i sat relaxed and open the box to See 20 edamame beans in number, 4, 5 tiny squares cod pumpkin, some rocket salad leaves , half beetroot and some seeds and one more thing. Not to say that all was flat and not Even making a bit of volume. It look ed like a meal for a 5 years old boy. Taste was great but please why do u hav to take a Piss off people who want to est healthly!!! I d feel imbarrased to serve food in that way! So a big no no for me. There r more plenty of places out there which serve raw food and i can understand it can b expensive but at least keep in mind a more desirable honest portion.

QGYUtAwH291EeE3Z_6YBmg.text: All of the food we ordered was very good.  The hot chocolate really stands out as the best we've ever had.  Service was also very good, despite a crowded restaurant.  I really want to give them five stars, but the prices make that impossible.

cVHtHd1dXVzHYOGeVniAvw.text: demiscious Raw Food and the Smoothie was soooo good :)! quite pricy but its worth it ;)

3sOGQPIvPdN43DRJPO0zyA.text: So, I came here and the food wasn't bad at first. It tasted much better than I thought it would, but it made me feel really I'll later... it was really all I ate, so I know it was that restaurant. Yuck

VBUKEjUv5b8mh21C65VY8w.text: A new concept cafe serving an innovative and fairly priced menu of raw-centric gourmet Wild Food world cuisine, smoothies and juices, soups and snacks, coffee, tea, confectionery and desserts, as well as fresh-from-the-tree chocolate and coconut delicacies and drinks.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Alligator smoothie (not made with real alligators!)

lB0_TEzD4lahrbLNjKspWg.text: Super tasty vegan food, but watch out, its pricey!! Quite suprising really for a bunch of hippies!

Tzzl05UWdZ_4yD_muGg2qA.text: I could eat here everyday.  Absolutely delicious and hearty salad to share over a quaint tucked away square in a fun neighborhood.  The daily fresh hummus was wonderful (with the homemade crackers). Presentation of food was wonderful and staff very friendly. A little oasis for two west coast American vegans in a land of fried meats.

bzluIiRq0t-Q9KY5nr45sw.text: I'm not orthorexic so this probably wasn't the restaurant for me but I do appreciate good food of any kind.Overpriced health food with poor service sums it up.The gazpacho soup was literally (yes literally!) clear, cold water with a little stock, some oil floating on top and a few small squares of cucumber and pepper. It was definitely not gazpacho and was sold as containing "big juicy tomatoes".  I mentioned this to the waiter who said the tomatoes have been "squeezed".The falafel main dish was falafel without any chickpeas and without the falafel and actually quinoa grain soaked in water on the hardest, toughest, strange, quasi-bread-like-stuff.  A selection of unidentifiable soft, wet vegetables on top.I've had good macrobiotic fair and good vegetarian but this was ridiculous and the "ginger beer" was so slow to be made I'd already finished my main dish.  Probably good job too as my friend let me taste his - crushed ginger root in cold water which is not ginger beer in anybody's book.To be fair if you're really into raw food you'll probably appreciate this place more than myself.

WTYlUPEoD4_wwunqDijxDQ.text: I loved the healthy fresh food on a second floor cafe in the coolest street in Coventry Gardens.  Some waitstaff are inexperienced so the service was a bit slow but totally worth the wait. Recommended especially the yummy blood orange juice and bittersweet dark chocolate cake

UVmMcpCU8SfunEUnjENXSQ.text: rawfoodscotland.com/2012… This is not my review but it's a good one and I cannot wait to try it for myself, even though it means that one f my old favourites has left the site  this looks even better.

jEP8nxF856EAqZuvKC3ZgQ.text: kale chips - amazing!wild burger is very good as well, veggie friends would love it!

Mtvq8DxU13cRIZpUj__1eQ.text: Great intimate and friendly space - a little oasis in central London. Stunning vegan food, the best I've had. Busy and no reservations, so had to wait a little to be seated. Completely worth it though! And quick service once seated. I'll be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom

hKyzsAj0IPT7ig4-rpu48w.text: I paid a visit to a vegie restaurant, Wild Food Café at Neil's Yard, Covent Garden. The café is upstairs. If you don't mind some leaflets about yoga and other spiritual stuff lying about, this is a very welcoming dining space. It was very busy but staff were very friendly and helpful. Crunchy kale chips were seasoned with salt and some mixed spice. It was good to see someone doing something positive with kales. We wanted a hummus to complete the starter but they were out. So we ordered butternut squash dip. It was little bit mashy and dry. The main salad consisted of green leaves, avocado, tomato, roasted nuts in mustard dressing. The salad was a true delight. The dressing was a refreshing mix of mustard and slightly fruity sauce. I also ordered a raw cheese cake as dessert. Mind you, my experience up to this point of raw cakes in general had never been overtly positive. The cheese cake was certainly not as good as any baked (or otherwise) cake, but this one was the best raw cake I'd had. It had the texture of mashed tofu and had none of the richness of normal cheese cakes. Chocolate mint cake that my friend ordered was better. It tasted like, well, chocolate and mint. Exactly what it says on the tin. I am still unconvinced about raw cakes in general. With the recent closure of the other vegetarian restaurant at Neil's Yard, Food for Thought, I hope this one will keep going for years to come.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. kale chips and squash dip (hummus substitute)
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Raw cheese cake

oUhBDXwZOVr110gtZp5bWw.text: I've wanted to try Wild Food Cafe for over a year now but every time I go I get confused about the line, and how all the tables work. It turns out you just wait at the door and they plop you on a table corner or bench whenever one becomes available.Their menu is much more vast than you'd realise at first and while it is pricey the food is delicious. I had a few issues trying to find something to eat with my onion allergy, but they were accommodating and I was able to have the falafel wrap which was delicious, sweet potato fries which are always a winner, then I topped it off with their delicious chocolate smoothie, and split a chocolate/caramel raw cake and nut free bannoffee cake with my friend, both of which were delicious and very rich!The whole place is very busy, a little scattered and disorganised but there is no question that the food is great. It's not easy to find, given it's in Neal's Yard and then up the stairs but it's well worth it if you can deal with sitting at a table with 6 random strangers! I will certainly be back.

mTygN0z-DoOZahtMOK8aWQ.text: Hummus and raw crackers to die for! With Ayurvedic salad, you will feel like you've gotten the food experience, nutrition and flavor to last a week! We had lunch in the window over Neal Square and then came back the next night for dessert. While lunch service was brilliant, the dessert experience topped it. They let us in at the last minute and made us feel completely welcome for a vegan, gluten free chocolate tart (with yummy cocoa nibs and spices surrounding it) while they happily cleaned up around us. We cannot wait to be back in London just to come here. If only we had a restaurant like this near home! So charming.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Ayurvedic salad and hummus plate with raw crackers

AMfh5YFRk2PFFCh47vf2KQ.text: Very nice cafe in neal's yard. We've had a really good smoothie and some lemon cake. The Cake was a dream. Never had so happy and friendly staff. I think, they really like to work there. Miss it

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Green Power

IdhgZ4rtrO_efXGljS_ifQ.text: The best. The food and atmosphere here are so wonderful. I love the open kitchen and creative dishes. One of my all time favorite places to eat in London.

l8HfUCiikBzfuC06HQjz0w.text: Came here on my trip to London, not knowing what to expect, and really loved it. The food is packed with flavor, unique, and pretty to look at. And it is filling. I had the hummus with raw crackers (shared w/ friend), Ayurvedic salad, and raw chocolate cake (shared w/ friend).  The food doesn't come in humongous portions, but the amount I had was definitely enough for a filling lunch. I definitely suggest trying some of the flavorful raw crackers, which was arguably better than the hummus (which was also delicious). And the cake was rich, creamy, and delectable. I came with an omnivore, who absolutely loved his meal and was pleasantly surprised that raw vegans didn't dine on wilty bland leaves all the time!I also got one of the mushroom teas -- I think it was the energy one. Tasted like the traditional bitter Chinese medicines my mom made me drink as a kid. And I did not feel boosted with energy. Meh, pass on that.

2PP9Ag_YLPmvhbXgOogqKQ.text: After my conversion to veganism a few weeks ago, I jumped at the chance to come to another raw/vegan/vegetarian restaurant, dragging along a companion who was likely not as enthused as I was to be there, but was nonetheless agreeably game about visiting.Wild Bird Cafe is nestled in a building in Neal's Yard, in an upstairs--I'm not sure you'd find it and wander in if you hadn't made it a destination to begin with. We went on a stifling hot and muggy day, and there was no AC, so the temperature hung down on us. Upon first choosing to sit by the windows (there is a large area just open to air) we promptly change our minds when I cannot handle the sunlight attacking my face and choose to sit at the bar, while we try to make do with the slug-like progression of the ceiling fan directly above us and the desk fan next to us. The counter-space/bar-space separates us from the "kitchen," so you can see everything happening, as well as all the employees making it happen. Bowls of courgettes, peppers, and lemons litter the space.The walls are hung with trippy, LSD-like paintings, and the chirpy employees are of the dreadlock-wearing, top-knot-tying variety (I spotted a Tree of Gondor tattoo on our server's leg). The menu includes things like 'turkish olives with activated almonds and 'Organic gluten-free un-baked sundried tomatoe & sunflower seed cracker.' We both order a 'vegan cider'--I ask the server what that even means and she tells me that usually the preservatives in regular cider isn't vegan--and he gets the raw chocolate berry cake, and I go for the lemon cheezecake (also raw). The lemon cheesecake was bright and had a strong lemon flavor--you wouldn't be able to tell that all its ingredients were raw--and his cake was dense and moist, but not too sweet at all.I can't speak for the food, but I'm sure it is delicious, the servers were incredibly nice, and if you enjoy the hippie-esque vibes of vegan restaurants, you should definitely add this on the list.

7pSw9WvC-fKx5bdrZSHDkQ.text: Ticks all the boxes. Great communal space. Friendly staff and super honest clean and healthy food with axons rant innovation. Think #raw #vegan #glutenfree #refinedsugarfree goodness!

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Kombucha and "ecstasy" chocolate smoothie
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Raw cacao vegan avocado tart

5LMHcQBWkxjSVEhep3ZZKA.text: Came here for lunch with a friend. It was very busy and we were squeezed onto a table with other people. I think they're going for a social vibe but it just makes it awkward eating whilst sitting squished up next to strangers. The main courses are extortionately priced (but you can get everything takeaway which makes it slightly cheaper, I'll definitely do this next time). My friend had a falafel wrap for £13.50 and she was disappointed with it- small and highly average. I opted to just get a side and a dessert to lower the cost. The sweet potato fries (£4) with delicious, very well cooked with just the right amount of cinnamon. And the raw chocolate and berry cake (£5) is the reason I almost gave this place 5 stars. Seriously the best cake I've had in London. Never tasted anything like it. Absolutely outstanding and the reason that I will return. Multiple times! Also the staff are lovely!

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Raw chocolate and berry tart, take away, 4.16
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Falafel wrap (13), sweet potato fries (4), raw chocolate berry cake (5)

gI_bdpb41u3m_9quAKTjTQ.text: Another vegan restaurant review! This occasion bringing me to the Wild Food Cafe in Neal's Yard.This first-level restaurant is airy and bright despite its very small size. The atmosphere is friendly and the music level is perfect to foster a comfy vibe.It's a pretty communal seating set-up but tables are fully stocked with water, glasses, and napkins (recycled too *eco smiles*).The waiting staff are pleasant and knowledgable though it would have been nice to have a sign to say "sit where you like" rather than stand around waiting to be seated.An order of coffee is cheap and you get a small cafetière's worth - which is about three cups - with a choice of milks (coconut is the one you want). The Ayurvedic salad I had was the perfect portion size to get me full but not bloated and the taste was beautifully fresh and interesting. My only gripe with it was that it was a pretty plain salad with all the interesting stuff dumped on top - I wish it had been incorporated better.I also had the raw vegan tart which tasted fresh, lemony, and generally very tasty but for the slightly grainy texture.I was happy to learn that everything on the menu is vegan (barring an item with halloumi) so you don't have to play find-the-things-I-came-here-for.Another minor thing is that some of the stock is stored under the benches (it really is that small); it disrupted the meal a bit to have someone pulling a jar of pickles out of my seat. Having said that it was great to have a full view of the kitchen and to see how cleanly and well organised the ingredients were stored.Overall I was very happy with the taste and attention to detail. A few rough edges did make an impression - but not enough to warrant dropping a star. I will definitely be back :)

w7gWkgKpnFUYNeXoHVULgw.text: I'm kind of torn about this place. On one hand, the food is always delicious, inventive and plated beautifully. On the other hand, it takes nine years to actually get your food. Lest you think I am exaggerating, during my last visit, I spent exactly 1 hr 5 minutes at the venue; 55 min ordering and waiting and 10 minutes eating.Again, the food was great and I keep coming back but by 30 minutes in, I am usually in a strange opposite zen state where I am unable to make conversation with my companions and only able to size up the other diners; who came after I was seated, who can I destroy to obtain my entree first, how are some people just eating thier meals and ignoring the torture being doled out to the rest of us, WHAT IS LIFE? And then the food finally comes and it's so pleasing and delicious and my anxiety disappears and I am so happy to be here and so glad that I waited and the murderous impatience of fellow diners still waiting to be served seems so unjustified now. I will probably be back. Wahhh.

aomPqxz5_8o-vPlTrx_uUw.text: This restaurant is situated in Neal's Yard, which is an adorable shopping square in Covent Garden. I had the Wild Cult sandwich. It was good, but the sandwich part was hard to eat (it was open faced). The grain bread was good as well. My friend had the (raw vegan) pizza, topped with lots of vegetables, and it looked pretty good. The servings are quite small, so it's not a great value for your money. However, the huge windows and plentiful natural light made it a great dining experience.

vgVJs6krPOyv9ewEAAUcDQ.text: Beautiful spot over looking Neal's yard courtyard. All items are vegan and the menu is very intriguing and everything sounds delicious. Their locally sourced ciders and smoothie was to die for. The sweets looked amazing and the salads and pizza as well. Everything is refined sugar free, dairy free, and animal free. I could see myself coming here quite frequently if I lived on the right side of the Atlantic Ocean. Great concept, wish there were more places with this large of a vegan menu back home. Their special board is great too, try it out!!

FGb7Zkvd7xx_T1FVsoerpg.text: This place is fine. It definitely has an insiders vibe though. Probably half the customers are regulars and this results in lots of hugging and for non-regulars to wait a relatively long time.My dish was decent except for the hair in my mushroom burger. What was more alarming was that I couldn't figure out whose hair was in my burger since the kitchen is open and no one cooking had that color hair.....still it has decent food and a wonderful atmosphere. Will come back and try again! Hopefully no hair this time.

6Ksy4j2AKsWsXHXGzgywRQ.text: A vegan paradise!  Gourmet quality recipes and preparation. Terrific service, especially considering the cramped quarters of the small restaurant.  Seating is tight, but the place is clean and in a great location.  My mother and I both loved it.  Nourishment and well being is what you leave with.  By far, the best vegan restaurant we tried while in London.

HEoiKRHqBlYT0GDm3L7Cvg.text: Fueled by sourdough, mushrooms, and cocoa/fig/dateshake, I roam London.I'm in the UK for work and wish I could bring Wild Food Cafe back with me to New England. I had a delicious lunch there reconnecting with a friend; the vegetarian/vegan menu was perfect after a red-eye flight.I had the wild mushrooms on toast, which left me satisfied for the afternoon. And the Forgotten Ecstasy smoothie is not to be missed - raw cocoa, figs, dates, coconut, and all kinds of goodies left me smiling but not heavy as I headed out to hit bookshops and explore the city before returning to work.  Keep up the innovative work, Wild Food!  It's always nice to see a vegetarian place showing people the amazing satisfying meals we can make from plants.

p5S5bf6lVWoptV6PEX26CA.text: love this place. the Ayurvedic salad is filling but in the healthiest and most satisfying way possible. the banana bread was also very well plated though lacking in taste in comparison to the salad. very friendly staff and great location.

ib6Aq2n8Ndc6NIXMFyMhbQ.text: Great atmosphere! It's a quirky little place with friendly people and lovely fresh food. I enjoyed a smoothie and just hung out for a while. I love that the kitchen is right there in the open.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Smoothie at the bar
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. The cafe is upstairs

2-K31QE52KVE0RosXEqotw.text: There are only a handful of Vegan restaurants that I'd go to in London and Wild Food Cafe is one of them.The smoothies are just great. And they have kale chips, my all time fav healthy snack.. The only downside is it's very small and when the restaurant is busy. It can be a bit of a squeeze.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Power balls for a busy day  #YelpEveryDamnDay

vYEQFkSHXcq5VkxF9cdUPA.text: Wonderful, wonderful spot right in the middle of Neal's yard -gets busy at lunch

EAwMc1MoBz9jU4NUP5N7SA.text: So, I came here with very the almost no expectations. I have recently turned to a plant-based diet and the only reason I was looking forward to come here was that I wouldn't have to hunt for something I could eat--the whole menu would be suited to someone like me. But then again, with everything on the menu being plant-based and cooked below 42°F, I failed to see how my palate would be happy after the meal.I was so wrong. And I am happy for that. I dragged an omnivore friend along with me and both of us enjoyed our meals. I had the cult sandwich with kale chips and it was divine. The cashew nut aioli it came with was the bomb. And I could've happily gorged on those kale chips till I was ready to burst. My friend had the pizza which was amazing too. Now it wasn't your usual pizza and the base was made of an almond and butternut squash. And it was smeared with some amazing marinara. Overall, very satisfying--even for the omnivore. We had the smoothies--white zen & forgotten ecstasy--too and they were delicious. But the star of the show had to be the wild banoffee pie. I can't even begin to tell you how good it was. Don't go plant based, don't eat all the other stuff on the menu, but do come here for that banoffee pie. You will not be disappointed.I could eat here practically everyday!

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Wild banoffee pie
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Wild pizza
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. The wild cult sandwich with kale chips

Y9lGTM2FsVYWN8z5iDQoAA.text: I hadn't been to Neals Yard for a while, so glad to see that nothing much has changed!  A bit confused about the name, though - and having done some googling, it turns out that the Wild Food Cafe did indeed replace my former favourite World Food Cafe.It still looks the same, and you have to climb up the same steep staircase, even the interior hasn't changed - and they are still vegetarian!  But what used to be a cheap and cheerful veggie treat with dishes from around the world has become a slightly more serious restaurant.  Well, at least the prices are serious.  I enjoyed my fresh fennel soup despite its £6 price tag.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom

4s_F-XBr-SK_Rj_qqo1vvg.text: Nothing to write home about and probably won't visit again unless it's for the chocolate cake which is DELISH!

q7ZQLSy-TWUz4kpMfQDO8Q.text: The food was excellent!  My daughter and I walked in on a whim.  The welcome was warm and our dishes were excellent!  My daughter had a pizza with soup and I had a salad.  The desserts are superstars, especially the chocolate sundae that they made for my girl.

0l-CLaomX_Lr48BuRktcWQ.text: Really enjoyed this not so  "hidden" gem (now). I am a meat eater and I would have prevent ordering salad at all costs when going out to eat. However since I've been to this place I am now eating less meat and more vegetable. The way this place does its magic to the raw ingredients, it still make my taste bud dancing on air with questions of how and what and this can't be raw food! Yes you are correct these desserts -cheesecake has no diary in it. I am longing for a receipe book to make these delicious dishes at home. The only reason I gave this a 4 stars because of the busy crowded seating arrangement. Shame it is not a bigger cafe!

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. raw chocolate cheesecake or order from their speciality board, the raw white chocolate cheesecake!
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. The wild falafel wrap with pistachio, hummus and tahini. Sides: baked sweet potatoes!
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Raw lemon pistachio cheesecake (vegan attle)

ot9DZleakP88_9McTml2Hg.text: I looked for a vegetarian restaurant around my hotel and this place popped up 1st on Yelp. Omg. OMG! It was one of the best salads I have ever had. I started with a "spring in your step"  juice that was fresh and sweet. The Japanese Kale Salad was out of this world. I can't recommend it enough. I just HAD to try dessert because I was so impressed with my meal and I was so glad I did. The lemon cheesecake was not only so beautiful on the plate, it was delicious. The staff was so very nice. Great ambiance. Casual and laid back. Will go back for sure while I'm in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Lemon cheesecake. Woah. Delicious!

-omhdfEzw6mZZsimuUFHbA.text: We had the most fantastic lunch at wild today. I was impressed that they had Kombucha on their menu, which was delightful. I ordered the pizza which was great, and my mom had the veggie burger. They both came with small salads with some arugula in with the greens. The atmosphere was also really special. We sat next to two other women and they gave us recommendations. It was really nice.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. This is the aftermath from a beet and chocolate torte.
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Veggie burger. Nom nom nom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. My beautiful pizza!!

xxaTCOR-VMzVz1-wZ63y2g.text: I really, really, really wanted to love this place- so colourful in a wonderful setting, massively allergy aware and I ruddy love vegan food, but it wasn't to be so...We walked up, and although there weren't many people there, it felt like there was nowhere to sit as the arrangements are a little odd- so we sat at the counter. We were less than a metre away from some of the staff, and we weren't greeted or even looked at.They weren't rude, but it was like we weren't even there, which was just a bit odd. We sat for ten minutes, and we just didn't feel inspired or like we were really very welcome. And when we were ignored because two of the staff were busy spooning behind the counter like it was a bank holiday morning, we decided to go. I'll try it again at some point because the food looks amazing, I don't know if it was just a bad day!

SMNN7Pd0JhyXK6cFzfwRgA.text: If you love raw vegan cuisine I'd definitely recommend a visit to this popular little café nestled in the heart of Covent Garden. Small menu, but I like that, everything has to be fresh and it was. The raw crackers and hummus was delicious. I was sitting within easy reach/sight of the waitresses and this may have contributed to the good service I received (other reviews seem to pinpoint service as an issue). The doorway was completely manic as there isn't a place to wait inside meaning people were queuing on the narrow stairs and blocking the doorway. The toilets weren't great either. It may be possible that it has outgrown this location and would benefit from a move to a larger site.

N3ibLkmyEl-BC6Q-k_X6Fw.text: Very cozy and nice vegan food. Clean menu - Fantastic atmosphere and good prices. I Will be back next time a go to London.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Lovely vegan food, small but cozy. I Will be back :-)

OKkEOA7LJ3gQt4LbmbIqAw.text: I didn't particularly enjoy the Ayurvedic salad or the raw crackers. We got our table quickly, service was good. The smoothie was great though. Overall safe bet. At one point, I thought it was a bit too noisy but it isn't much of a problem really. The cafe is located in the beautiful Neal's Yard which is a plus. Go for it!

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom

fu0XGbL81-6-2klMBWMKAg.text: Everything we ordered was delicious, but like other reviewers mentioned, the pricey are high. We ordered 2 soups, burrito, salad, and 2 juices and the bill was 60 pounds. My husband said it's his favorite vegan place in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Burrito and salad. Delicious!

h0pDesI8hqgJm5MTc69HHw.text: Review from Beca & Yana at SeekNPlay.coWild Food Cafe is located in the peaceful, healthy haven that is Neal's Yard, one of Covent Gardens secret gems, home to Neal's Yard Remedies and other small businesses. Many people are unaware that this place exists unless stumbling across it when walking around the little streets in Seven Dials. Stepping in to the yard feels like and instant escape from London's crazy hustle and bustle, a place where you can clear your mind and forget you are standing in a city of 8.7 million people.The Wild Food Cafe is here to promote aliveness and embody a world in which plant-passionate, nutrient-packed food that is prepared and served with love is not only possible,  it is necessary! We arrived at a perfect time of 5.30 pm, being able to walk straight through the big blue door, up the stairs and seated comfortably at one of their communal tables without having to queue. Which I've heard is rare.Although a fairly small venue, there was a great atmosphere of lively chatter and enjoyment of the food. The staff had a major role in this, with their positive attitudes and willingness to answer questions about the menu.After skimming over the mouth-watering menu several times, we finally ordered. It didn't take long for our drinks to come out.I went for the Forgotten Ecstasy: Summer Edition (£7) Acai berries, blueberries, lavender with raw cacao powder, cacoa butter, fresh coconut milk, dates, he-shou-wou extract, maca, algarroba, coconut cream and maple syrup. Wow what a concoction hey... many of these ingredients I have never heard of before, cue the research. Forgotten Ecstasy was rich and filling but in a good way, the strong chocolate taste with a subtle hint of berries and lavender is a winner from me and something I will get again on my next visit.Danielle went for the Make Your Own juice (£6) Apple, Pear and Cucumber fresh and simple tasting but apparently delicious.The gorgeous Danielle devoured the Indian Split Pea Soup & Superseed Bread (£7), the flavour of the day, this is suggested as a starter but is more than enough to have as a main. After much begging Dani allowed me to have a taste, not a major soup fan, this was perfection and wouldn't ordering this on my next visit. So pleased I went for the #TGBOAT , the price not so much at a whopping £16.70. I added the Cashew Aioli for an extra £2, not worth it, but I will let it slide. The meal was just what I needed. The root vegetable jerk burger , and lots of other ingredients, was an explosion of flavoursome ingredients and far better than any meaty burger I have ever had... big statement but it's true. Normally I am one to eat everything off a menu, after my drink and main I had to admit defeat as I could not fit in another crumb. It is safe to say that you won't leave the table feeling hungry! The food and overall experience was hands down spot on. The only thing that would stop me visiting weekly would be the price tag, but it is understandable considering how they source the natural produce and keep to the promise of everything being completely fresh.Joel and Aiste, the owners, have certainly poured their heart and soul into making the Wild Food Cafe such a success. Their love to encourage healthy eating and passion of promoting the endless possibilities of creating so many wonderful plant based dishes.All I can say is visit the Wild Food Cafe and see what you think.It has not only opened my eyes to trying out different produce but it has also inspired me to look at more vegetarian recipes. I am already planning my next trip and this time I will make room for pudding...the Raw Chocolate Tart is calling my name !Thanks for reading.

2ipLkh9VwcaUbnDXulI_vw.text: I have been coming here for 8 years and I love this place! I meet clients here although it's not ideal for that a bit cramped. The staff and food are excellent I always have the extacy smoothie and all the food is awesome. I usually get the salads:)

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom

LYOKPqCQNiVjAmFKf-rz9w.text: To summarize: the service was pretty flaky and sporadic, but the food was to die for.I had a pretty awful time finding this place because it is on a tiny side street called Neal's Yard....and I smartly kept wandering around Neal's St. So just be aware of that possible mistake.We went up and sat down on the communal tables (only communal tables or bar seating) and could not for the life of us get ourselves to be noticed. It is a pretty small restaurant and the waiter gave a menu to the group that sat next to us, but would not come to greet us or give us a menu. I tried to make eye contact with him but every time we would engage he would look away. Finally a waitress at the bar realized we had not been helped yet and gave us a menu. This is basically how the service continued to work, the wait staff is not assigned particular jobs, they are just supposed to walk around and take care of whatever needs to be done and I felt that this method left room for many gaps in their service. I ordered the pizza and my mom got the soup of the day.Once we got the food we were hooked! The food is quite expensive but the freshness, flavors, and combination of ingredients made it all worth it! We were oohing and aahing at every bite!Then the pains with the wait staff kicked in again. I had noticed a specials dessert menu on the far wall, but it annoyingly had the items written in alternating dark purple and blue chalk. The dark purple was completely impossible to read against the black chalkboard so I went to ask for a dessert menu. The waitress completely dismissed me and pointed to the board and said that that was their menu and walked away. Wrong. That was just the specials dessert menu and I could not even read it! We then asked another waitress and she kindly brought us the menu. The two desserts I wanted were out of stock so we just got the chocolate cake which was decent. An overall disappointing experience in terms of service, but the main dishes were so delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate cake.
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Their pizza! Also a must try.
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Carrot and orange juice. Highly recommended!

qI2S0GwY1TPKydI60EV4Vw.text: Best vegan restaurant I have ever been to. I went three times in the span of seven days! The Summer Goddess Salad and the Tahini brownie are heavenly!

MNWBRCboeRhLTcSf4wKnZg.text: This is for me the Temple of raw vegan in London. Tucked into and overlooking Neal's Yard, a decent communal space with ever changing choices (all raw and dehydrated). The burger is the staple but so many of the dishes are succulent. Love the desserts too: the cheesecake is the real McCoy.Amazing friendly service too (for central London)

L8QJLUwLrbJgQd9XRhEEFg.text: Great spot for those in London that are looking for a healthy food joint...especially raw food place. This place makes eating out healthy, finally. I enjoyed the food. It was tasty and presentation was on point. But the portions were definitely small for the prices. Also, it takes forever to get your food. I understand the care and all the fresh ingredients that goes into a plate, but it was overboard. I sat at the bar where you can watch everything in action and it was just snail pace. Good food, nice people, but don't think I'd frequent here.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom

sstIzoEK-6ftyM-jMFw56w.text: Wild food cafe is a cozy, comfortable restaurant nestled in Covent Garden they offer a great selection of raw food/ some cooked options. Majority of their food is prepared under 42 degrees C to preserve nutrition, enzymes and flavors. Wild food cafe is a place where you would want to go to relax unwind and honor the food you are eating. All of their food is organic and wild crafted. I was in a 5 star restaurant but for half the price. They are very creative with their dishes and it's also affordable. I ordered: from favorite to least fav.1. Grilled butternut squash bruschetta- If you are crazy about butternut squash you have to get this. 2. Apricot spiced hummus - hummus done the right way, very tasty 3. Ayurvedic super salad -  So many flavors in one dish and extremely healthy 4. Chickpea tofu salad - Not a fan of tofu, but I could eat this againDessert 1. Wild banoffee pie - melts in your mouth and is so light and delicate, kind of like a toffee creamy flavor.Please see Instagram: @brandyespi for more food reviews all around the world.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Butternut squash bruschetta
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Ayurvedic super salad

fh5QJ3sk4I9TL7AhjkrWPw.text: Wild Food Cafe is a cute, cozy cafe offering some aesthetically pleasing vegan food.For some reason, I didn't feel like the menu was very extensive, in fact it was a bit light. However, I wasn't starving and the "cauliflower wings" happened to be just the right size and hit the spot. I understand they were trying to be fancy with the flavors, but I could have done without the nori, which I picked off as it didn't seem to fit the dish.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Delicious, beautiful vegan cauliflower "wings".

fRMpKCeNAy3s9Vl_ac0B8A.text: Absolutely, phenomenally, healthy, tasty and flavorful at the same time!They need this cafe in every city in the world Would recommend 10/10

J924xBNDSkS56GfXsL6TPQ.text: This food is excellent. Although my girlfriends food came out about 10 minutes prior to mine, our meals itself were delicious (flavor 10/10). I got the Green Burger, which was crazy flavorful but not very filling and a bit messy. My girlfriend got the buck wheat toast, a side of avocado, and the side of sweet potato/aioli. She's was very happy with her sides/dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom

F1HZu-sCPA_djrzL7A4bGQ.text: 3.5I truly enjoyed my experience, really nice staff!I'd recommend going slightly off hours cause it's a small space. Luckily I was by myself so I got a spot. I got the bruschetta (butternut squash as the bread w asparagus and tomatoes and vegan pesto + cheese), and was disappointed that I paid so much for vegetables, but I can't deny that it was delicious. The butternut squash replacement for bread is a bit sad, but I guess healthy.I got the lemon poppy bread with pistachio creme. Pass, it was pretty dry.The presentation is fantastic though, maybe this place is suited for those who appreciate the vegetarian/vegan style. And are willing to pay for it.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Butternut squash bruschetta
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Lemon poppy bread with pistachio cream

FwAzSDLexWxOTJIObBQ_LA.text: Just love this place.....It is not a high end fancy restaurant but a cafe. I am a low fat plant based eater, and they were willing to help me find the right meal to eat. The people working there are amazing, the food is amazing, the ambiance is amazing.One of my favorite places in london.

ZAL-1y7U-Oeg80fgsFZ9cw.text: This place is in such a nice area. The exterior is beautiful as well. I especially enjoyed the colorful and motivating stairway up to the restaurant. The options are food are also great and incredibly healthy. I enjoy fresh and healthy food, so this was right up my alley.Unfortunately, the service wasn't the best and the Venus Bowl was OK. I wound up sitting at the bar and had to call for people when I wanted to order and to pay. They didn't seem to acknowledge me much. It was a bit frustrating. The Venus Bowl also wasn't that great. It felt a bit dry and definitely not worth 15 pounds for one dish.I wouldn't recommend this place as a must-go for friends visiting London. The area it's in is nice to walk around though.

fAfxD-9WwMruNuU9Uers9g.text: This vegan cafe hiding in Neals Yard, it is easy to missed it if you walked past Neal street. it was busy when we arrived and it took a while to wait for the table. Menu dishes look great but the price is expensive. Ordered one soup...two salads main dishes and one dessert....wow..the price is about £50.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom

waC9KKMdWP6CUpEvCjgUhA.text: Super vegan cafe, a little bit overwhelming. The cafe is on the second floor, and pretty small within Neal's Yard. Went at 1-2pm on a Saturday and it was extremely busy, and I had to wait 20 minutes to get a seat. I enjoy vegan food but the main entree that I got, the ramen noodles, were a little bit too healthy for me, and I didn't really feel too full after. I purchased a raw chocolate tart which I enjoyed tremendously, it was the perfect amount of sweetness. Overall, the restaurant was pretty expensive and I probably wouldn't come back because of the prices.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. raw chocolate tart
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. noodles

QARst3jwBeabuKwkEGtfPg.text: I googled "raw vegan London" and Wild Food Cafe was one of the top results. I happened to be somewhat nearby, so I decided to walk over. Neal's Yard, where Wild Food Cafe is located, must have been a real treat a few years back; it's its own cute little courtyard-like area surrounded by shops and greenery. The buildings all look fun and are brightly colored, and the area itself is pretty -- you can see it if you're seated at one of the windows in the cafe, as it's located just about the Neal's Yard Remedies Shop. Now, though. the area is crazy busy and touristy. I imagine that's one of the reasons Wild Food was so packed when I went on a Saturday afternoon at 4 pm. The other is that the food is delicious. To be fair, I only ordered a slice of banoffee pie, but as I was seated at the bar I saw so many other dishes being prepared and they all at least looked amazing. The lady who prepared my pie (who was super nice, btw) took so much care when assembling it. It was art, there's no other way to put it. I agree with some of the other reviewers, the prices are a little steep (steeper if you're from somewhere like the US where the $ to £ conversion rate hurts a little. I did keep in mind that I was in central London in a touristy area, though, and at least I can say what I ordered was both beautiful and delicious! One slight hiccup in my experience: I stood next to the "please wait to be seated" sigh at the entrance, and one of the waitresses looked at me a few times without seating or acknowledging me. Then, she tried to seat me at a table with three other people when there were a few seats at the bar available. Glad the food was good because that quickly fell to the back of my mind! Oh and FYI: My pie came to just about £8 (with an "optional" tip added automatically).

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Swooning over someone else's dessert being prepared.

yJugvPk1OTi2jQA9nRCTeQ.text: What can I say. The presentation is overwhelming. The location is overwhelming. The service is impeccable. I have never eating a meal so interesting, beautiful, flavourful, and vegan before. Was it the best meal I ever had? No. But boy was it memorable.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. The most beautiful thing I have ever eaten
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Trust me it tastes delicious

GV0AAhIyAhvX-nIt7BBJFA.text: And they say you can't find good food in England.... thanks to this little natural plant-based food oasis we are stuffed to the hilt....We ordered the Apricot Hummus on Raw Crackers, the Samurai Burger, the Quan Yin Bowl, and the Raw Chocolate Torte. All were worthy of the Clean Plate Club seal of approval!  What a find, thanks Yelp!

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Apricot Hummus on Raw Crackers
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Samurai Burger
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Quan Yin Bowl

Pl4jKYkUdfBeG3KC5LdHdg.text: This is a pretty popular place and it's all vegan - from burgers, sandwiches, crackers, salads, and desserts, there are a lot of choices to be had. Certainly a good option for the vegetarians/vegans out there. I like healthy food and crave a good salad, but felt like this place fell short for me compared to the price/quality/taste of salads elsewhere. This place is located up the stairs in Neal's Yard, next to Home Slice. Go up the stairs and you'll see a very colorful, small room. This is not the place to come with a large group - I'd say a party size of 4 is the maximum, but I'd recommend just coming solo or with one other person as there's not much room and there are mostly long communal tables.I got the Japanese kale salad. I normally really love kale salads, but this was a little too healthy-tasting for me, and I like salads and healthy things. I think it also had some butternut squash, mushrooms, pumpkin seeds, almonds, beets, and maybe eggplant. Proportionally, it was a little too much kale to the other ingredients and didn't feel that balanced. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't a salad I'd be craving again. It was also a bit expensive, I paid around £10.50 for the takeaway salad here, if I had eaten here, it was somewhere around £12-13, which is not cheap for a salad. I have to be honest, a salad at Pret-a-Manger for 1/2 the price would have probably been just as satisfying.I'd be willing to give this place another shot - maybe my salad was just off that day, but it is pricier than most other salad places in the area. If you're looking for vegan food, this is probably a decent bet, but if you're looking for just something healthy, there are a lot of other options nearby.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Kale Salad

awzGrWWNyfB7whnjZI9VkA.text: This place was my first experience in London's vegan-restaurant scene and I couldn't be more pleased with experience. The place was kind of hard to find initially as it is located in an upstairs alley way. However a large sign guides you in welcomingly to the door. I went on a Saturday and the place was PACKED!! They have a small bar space but anyone of any size may find it somewhat cramped.  I had the the soup of the day and the Wild Burger and they were both delicious. Additionally ALL of the wait-staff were friendly, personable and attentive. A definite try.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. People
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. They have beer!!
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. That face your friend makes when you take him to a Vegan restaurant.

Hmv7j60aAI9L0Onr7ePuug.text: I came to Wild Food Cafe for an afternoon pick-me-up after a long day of walking and exploring London. My cousin was getting a smoothie, and I didn't want to be jealous so decided to get one too. I chose the Alp-accino because the waiter told me it was voted the best drink in London, so I had to try it. The Alp-accino is a coffee smoothie, with interesting sounding ingredients such as moss and medicinal mushrooms (what even is that?) so I was a bit apprehensive at first to order it. We stood at the bar and watched as our drinks were made. Each smoothie has tons of different components, and the guy making them made them all look beautiful, with different toppings and whipped (coconut) cream. Mine ended up being delicious. I was so impressed that such a "healthy" smoothie didn't taste that healthy, it was more like a coffee & chocolate milkshake. Also coconut whipped cream is incredibly delicious...even better than normal whipped cream. I would definitely come back here next time I'm in London, but if I lived there I don't think it would be a go-to place because it is really expensive (7 pounds for a smoothie...). However, everything on the menu is plant-based, so this is a great spot to go with vegan or veggie friends.

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom

QxPqGgL2-Hei-MtFI0bmRQ.text: The Wild Food Cafe is an eclectic little restaurant on the second floor of a building in the Covent Garden district. It has an open kitchen layout and bench seating so do not expect a private dining experience as you will be shoulder to shoulder with your fellow diners. The atmosphere is typical of a vegan restaurant with inspirational messages about sustainability and hippy murals on the walls. The food unfortunately ruins any chance of a good review due to the incredible blandness. I ordered the burger with a side of kale chips. Each of the dishes were very tasteless and the burger was very dry even with the sauce that was on it. The strange bun is a dry disk of pressed grains which is quite tough and heavily detracts from the tastes of the interior of the burger. It also is brittle and falls apart making it required to use a knife and fork. The kale chips are also equally dull, which is sad because a little cayenne, rosemary, or cumin would definitely vastly improve the flavor of that side dish. Kale does not need to be like cardboard. I wanted so much to like this place, but the only redeeming factor is the decently priced wine. I will try back in a few months to see if they have improved.

Nl4AxsJOvMBGFnU-7hkqHA.text: It was really awkward when I first walked in because there is a sign that says wait to be seated but no one came so my friend and I were just standing there weirdly and people kept looking at us like we were crazy. However, after that mishap, it was all uphill from there. The food is INCREDIBLE. I honestly wanted to go raw after eating here. I had the mushroom toast with a side of avocado and the hot chocolate. It was all so amazing. It is pricey, but you get a good amount of food for what you pay. Really nice atmosphere and staff.

J5t5kS8TWywShu5maz8f6A.text: This place is truly a gem in London!  If it's your first time, a good tip is that it's up a flight stairs, on the second floor, from within Neal's Yard.  Look up!  All the shops in Neal's Yard are great (a little pricey) but if you like organic / vegetarian / vegan food & health products, then it's worth the price!  :)

oc94HdRi1F5VDBCxfW7T5w.text: I was here twice during my time in London and my experiences have been awesome! The raw hummus was delicious (I especially enjoyed the crackers) and my salad was a great combination of figs and hazelnuts. Although the portions are small, they're really delicate and delicious.The servers are all really friendly and they're willing to sit down and explain everything about the menu to you. When I was looking for a snack/dessert, one of the servers literally spent 15 minutes with me, answering all my questions. The ambiance is really cute as it overlooks Neals Yard. For a raw vegan place, Wild Food is a must visit in London and I'd recommend it to anyone!

photos.caption: Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Raw hummus with veggies and flax crackers
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Raw pizza
Photo of Wild Food Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Specials salad with figs, blueberries, hazelnuts, zoodles, carrots

pTDV2kO9CFXoKdmdZIF7yg.text: This really is vegan heaven! My husband and I who have been vegans since 1991 and 1990 respectively, went to this totally vegan and organic restaurant the other day and plan on returning again and again. The food is amazing and the staff are wonderful. Harry was warm and welcoming, charming and knowledgeable. I love desserts and so began with them. The raw cheesecake was not only aesthetically pleasing, but may well have been the best I have ever tasted. The banana bread, which I began the meal with as well was delicious and also presented in such a beautiful manner. Next, I had the sushi and sweet potato fries. This is definitely the place to visit if you are vegan and even if you are not, do try it. You will not regret it. We went a second time and it was just as wonderful as the first. My spouse had the raw courgette pasta and he loved it. I had desserts to begin, the raw cheesecake and the lemon verbena tart and sushi. Delicious! Even more delightful than the food was the wonderful person who served us, Reda. She was so warm and loving, exactly the kind of person you hope to meet in this life and she helps make this an absolute all time favorite in our traveling life.This restaurant knows that the people who work there make the food even better tasting than it already is, for they are amazing people serving amazing food.
